awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: GOALI: Identifying the roles of atomically dispersed Rh, support interactions, and environmental conditions in automotive NO reduction catalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Heterogeneous catalysis plays a vital role in keeping the environment clean. For example, catalytic converters in automobiles significantly reduce the environmental impact of the transportation sector by converting exhaust components to less harmful gases. Dramatic improvements in air quality since the 1970s in locations such as the Los Angeles basin underscore the enormous impact of heterogeneous catalysis on everyday life. Critical to the development of more efficient catalytic processes and the design of new catalytic materials is understanding the relationship between a catalyst's atomic structure and its function. It is expected that insights obtained during this research project will provide necessary information to guide the design of more effective catalysts, thereby enabling improvements in the performance and efficiency of catalytic converters. To promote unique educational opportunities provided by this research project, graduate students from the University of California-Santa Barbara and the University of Florida will visit Ford Motor Company's Research and Innovation Center in Dearborn, MI for three months each summer to continue research as visiting scholars. Undergraduate students will be involved in the research project and will learn from the topic through in-class modules. 

Three-way catalysts are the workhorse components of catalytic converters that achieve simultaneous oxidation and reduction of pollutants to less harmful species.  Typical metals at the active sites of three-way catalysts are Platinum (Pt), Palladium (Pd) and Rhodium (Rh). While Pt and Pd typically promote oxidation reactions, Rh plays a crucial role in commercial catalysts because of its ability to reduce nitrous oxide (NO) to dinitrogen (N2).  Despite its commercial importance, the mechanism of NO reduction on Rh active sites has remained largely elusive under relevant automotive working conditions. In this project, academic researchers will interface with an industrial partner to gain crucial mechanistic insights into the role of atomically dispersed Rh species in commercial three-way catalysts. Rigorous comparisons of the performance and mechanism of NO reduction chemistry under realistic conditions on atomically dispersed Rh and Rh clusters, as a function of environmental conditions and support composition, will be made. The research approach will combine kinetic studies, in-situ infrared and X-ray absorption spectroscopy, and density functional theory calculations. Results of this study will help guide the design of three-way catalysts and catalytic converter control systems for improved performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The implementation of catalytic converters in gasoline burning automobiles has significantly reduced emissions of pollutants such as NOx, NH3, CO, and hydrocarbons. Three-way catalysts (TWC) are used in catalytic converters to achieve simultaneous oxidation and reduction of pollutants to less harmful species over Pt, Pd and Rh active sites. While Pt and Pd are relied on for oxidation reactions of CO and unburnt hydrocarbons, Rh is primarily responsible for the reduction of NO to N2. However, significant amounts of N2O and NH3 are produced during the startup of automobiles and are environmentally detrimental. N2O is a potent greenhouse gas, and atmospheric NH3 is linked to particulate formation, ecosystem eutrophication, and decreased resilience of vegetation to exasperation, including parasites and drought. While extensive studies exist on the mechanism of NO reduction by extended Rh surfaces, the reaction mechanism is still not well understood in the TWC, particularly the specific structure of active Rh catalytic sites and the source of unwanted byproduct (NH3, N2O) formation. However, it is known that CO is the primary reductant for NO, although the participation of other reactants has been postulated.

 

Rh exists on Al2O3 and CeO2 supports used in TWCs as a mixture of structures from larger (> 10 nanometer diameter) particles to single Rh atoms, and such mixtures are persistent even after extended aging. The co-existence of many different types of Rh structures has made assignment of NO reduction reactivity to a particular Rh active site structure challenging. This project aimed to address these challenges and the associated knowledge gaps by performing a combined theoretical and experimental analysis of the structure, local environment, and reactivity of specific Rh active site structures under NO reduction reaction conditions.

 

Experimental and theoretical model systems were developed that enabled a correlated analysis of Rh active site structure under NO reduction reaction conditions and elucidation of the reactivity of these sites. It was identified that Rh single atoms produce unwanted NH3 at low temperature (~ 423 K) through the reaction: 2 NO + 3 H2O + 5 CO à 2 NH3 + 5 CO2. This was previously unknown as prior studies did not capture the role of water, which is present in automobile exhaust. Further, it was observed that Rh nanoparticles do not exhibit reactivity until higher temperature (~ 500 K), but selectively produce the desired product, N2. Thus, the two different structures of Rh active sites likely both contribute to observed reactivity in catalytic convertors, although Rh single atoms are responsible for the undesired formation of NH3.

 

The significant difference in NO reduction reactivity and selectivity on Rh single atoms and Rh nanoparticles suggests differences in NO reduction mechanism. Combined experimental and theoretical analyses provided insights into these differences.

 

In the case of Rh nanoparticles, during NO-CO reactions, NO adsorbs more strongly than CO and saturates Rh surfaces. The initial and rate limiting-step in this reaction is NO dissociation on an NO-saturated Rh surface. Additionally, it was identified that theoretical studies examining NO reduction should use small Rh nanoparticle model systems, rather than periodic Rh single crystals that are typically used, because nanoparticles result in adsorbed NO structures and coverages observed in experiment.

 

Alternatively, it was identified that CO preferentially binds to Rh single atoms on Al2O3 during NO-CO reactions, forming Rh geminal dicarbonyl species, Rh(CO)2. It was identified that the first and rate limiting step is CO desorption from Rh(CO)2 to produce an unsaturated site for NO adsorption. Further, water and hydroxyls on Al2O3 facilitated CO desorption by stabilizing the resulting Rh(CO) species. Finally, evidence was provided that NO reduction proceeds on Rh single atoms via mixed carbonyl-nitrosyl structures (e.g. Rh(CO)(NO)x). It was also found that theoretical studies examining this reaction mechanism should focus on HO-Rh(CO)2 as an initial state, as this provides consistency with experimental observables.

 

These results suggest that the difference in the reactivity of Rh single atoms and nanoparticles stems from their difference in adsorbate preference (CO vs NO), which dictates differences in kinetically relevant steps. Further, given the intimate Rh-support interactions for single atoms, water and hydroxyls on Al2O3 directly participate in chemistry at Rh single atom active sites, promoting their reactivity and providing a mechanistic pathway for H2O serving as the H-source for unwanted NH3 formation.

 

This project provided insights to industry regarding the design of TWCs and control systems to minimize NH3 formation by minimizing Rh single atom formation. Experimentally-informed theoretical active site model systems for Rh nanoparticles and Rh single atoms identify Rh local coordination environments under NO reduction conditions that provide insights into mechanistic differences and guide future mechanistic studies. Further, involved participants were educated in fundamentals of catalyst synthesis, characterization, theoretical interrogation, and reactivity measurements, as well as providing direct interactions between students and industrial partners to understand the potential impact of fundamental findings on industrial practice.
